Something about the " real-estate" model of higher dimensional spheres seems like it can give an interesting interpretation of Lp-space. In Lp-space, the concept of distance can be redefined with the "p-norm." Essentially, why is distance sqrt(x^2 + y^2)? In Lp-space, this is just the definition of distance when p=2, but it can be anything else! (Things are slightly different when p is odd, and if p is less than 1, then the result doesn't meet the criteria for a distance.) Setting p to 4 and then drawing the points equal distance from the origin, you get a lovely shape sometimes called a "squircle." Setting p to 1 actually gives the "taxi-cab metric."

In terms of real-estate, the different values of p define how the cost of the real-estate changes as it becomes further from the origin. When p is 1, then the cost of the real-estate is constant across the entire range, though still capped at a total of 1. In 2D, this is already enough touch the box, and in 3D, the inner "sphere" (which is actually an octohedron in this case) you've already escaped the inner box and simultaneously reached the outer box. If p is 4, the squircles are defined by (x^4 + y^4 + ...)^(1/4). The cost of the real-estate grows more slowly and the distance to the corner is now the 4th root of d (in dimension d). This gives the inner squircle very little room to work with in lower dimensions, having a radius of only about 0.19 in 2D, and it can't touch the inner box until reaching 16 dimensions!

Am I the only one who finds the expensive/cheap real estate metaphor to be exactly backwards?

When one slider has a lot of "real estate", that is, a large squared value, the slider only has to change a small amount in order to have a large effect on the "real estate". If the slider value is 'money' in this metaphor, that means the "real estate" is cheaper when you have more of it. You're buying or selling a lot of "real estate" (squared value) for only a small amount of 'money' (change of the slider). Likewise, when a slider has very little "real estate", it has to move a lot for a given change of real estate, so again if the slider itself represents money, that means the real estate is very expensive.

But the video keeps using the opposite metaphor, saying that the more real estate a slider has, the more expensive that real estate is. What's the equivalent of money in that metaphor? It's not the sliders, as that would yield exactly the opposite metaphor.

BTW, I think what kills most of us in terms of common sense are the tendency that we have to make judgements in terms of projections, and the projections from human experience are usually from 3D to 2D and sometimes to 1D, which don't generalize in the way we may expect. The spheres are touching at the diagonal of cube in N-space. The unitary diagonal is diag(N)= sqrt(N). The derivative is sqrt(1/4N) so it is always positive for N finite. The unit spheres have constant radii so all the growth has to be absorbed by the 'Incredible-Hulk' sphere at the corner so that they keep touching (the formula for Rinner(N) have the same derivative). So the trusty and seems to be infallible idea of thinking in term of projections fails to us (drops the ball!) badly in this case.

This takes 25mins to explain quite overcomplicated!?
The spheres of size 1 sit in the corners.
Each extra dimension just doubles the amount of corners each direction (face of the cube) has.
So the corners split, double and move to the sides into the added dimension, that each face now has and so they make space in the center of each face, where the center sphere can now grow into!
And the limiting factor is ofc the diagonal, where the inner sphere and outer spheres are touching.
So it's not that hard to imagine, why the inner sphere can grow outside the box.
It might be harder to imagine why the corners continue to offer enough space, while playing a less and lesser role.
It's because in the diagonals the dimensions add up geometrically.
And in the faces the diagonals of dimensions-1 grow as well and the corner-spheres move away from the centers of those faces.

That point about how far away the corners of the boxes are in higher dimensions is what really made this click intuitively for me. In higher dimensions, there's effectively more space for the outer spheres to fit into the corners of that outer bounding box, and they're located farther from the origin as a result. This leaves more space for that center sphere to take up while still being adjacent to the outer spheres. At no point, however, does the center sphere overtake the corners of either of the boxes.

I find it easier to grasp by looking at a similar 2D problem: suppose the outer circles are at (a,a), (a,-a), etc with a=sqrt(n/2) instead of one, and keep the number of dimension fixed at 2.

The radius of the inner circle is again sqrt(n)-1 but this time it is clear where it comes from: as n increases, the distance to the center of the outer circles increases (just like in the original problem) but their radius stays the same, so you need a larger inner circle to reach out to them.

There is nothing special about this larger circle expanding beyond the box a size 2a. You can visualize that easily in 2D with a large inner circle tangent to 4 very small outer circles.

Excellent video. This makes the counter-intuitive nature of high dimensions make sense. Here are a few facts that were just touched on in this presentation:

An infinite dimensional sphere has no volume, regardless of radius (volume has no meaning in an infinite dimensional space)

Every (multi dimensional) unit sphere contains all the unit spheres of lesser dimensions

In higher dimension spheres, the vast majority of the volume lies near the equator, as does most of the surface area

In higher dimension spheres, the vast majority of the volume lies near the boundary

The most efficient sphere packing in dimension 8 is E(sub 8), and in dimension 24, it is the Leech lattice

Each sphere in the dazzlingly symmetrical packing in the Leech lattice touches 196,560 other spheres

In 8 dimensions, the densest packing fills about 25% of space, and in 24 dimensions, the best packing fills only 0.1% of space

High dimensional hypercubes are spiky - as Dim for the unit hypercube goes up, the longest diagonal is sqrt(Dim)

easy way to visualize why the radius of the hyperspheres goes to and past 1...

In 1 dimension you can't fit anything between two 1-D spheres (i.e. lines). They touch each other.
In 2 dimensions there's more space, and when there are 4 circles you have room for a circle in between.
In 3 dimensions, you have 8 spheres. Imagine a cross-section of that along 4 of them, with your circle in between... the circle can get bigger because it "slips out" from being directly in line with the 4 spheres, having more room to grow into a bigger sphere before it hits the other 4.
And as you go up more and more dimensions it's the same- there's so much more room that you just slip out a bit more and more every time, until you have millions of little hyper spheres surrounding a much bigger inner hypersphere :)

I had a realisation during this video that really helped my understanding, so I wanted to share it. It involves thinking about the proportion of the n-dimensional cube's surface enclosed by the corner spheres.

In 2D space, all of the surface of the square is enclosed by the corner circles. There is no way to draw a line from the origin through the square without touching one of the corner circles.

When you move up to 3D space, you can already see this change. Focus on one square face of the cube. Notice the diamond shape that's not covered by any of the spheres. There's plenty of room to draw a line from the origin through the box without coming close to any of the spheres. In fact, it is this diamond shape that we filled in the 2D problem!

Things get a bit harder in higher dimensions, but our 3D visualisation can still help in the 4D case. Visualise the solution to the 3D problem. Think about all the space inside of the cube that we filled with the inner sphere, there's actually quite a lot of it. Now, in the same way you can visualise the 2D problem as one of the faces of the 3D problem, think about this solution to the 3D problem as one of the faces of the 4D problem. You can actually see how there's quite a lot of space there that's not covered by the corner spheres!

The visualisation breaks down after this point, but thinking inductively how each solution is a "face" of the problem one dimension higher, and how the space left over creates extra space for the next dimension to use was helpful for me.

I actually thought of a nice visual and intuitive understanding of this.
He says there’s no way to explain it with 3D and 2D analogies but I beg to differ.

If you don’t follow at any point please reply and let me know so I can explain and correct my comment.

So,
In 2 dimensions (9:45), it is clearly impossible for the inner circle to even touch the square because the nearest point on the square is also where the outer circles touch, therefore you cannot be touching the edge without touching the sphere too.

But in 3 dimensions (10:35, 21:31), (I’m gonna use the outer box for this), if you look at the point of the box the that is nearest to the centre, which is the centre of each face, the spheres no longer directly obstruct it as they did in 2D, and the last paragraph of logic no longer works. The spheres aren’t directly blocking the path to the nearest part of the cube, they are just forming a square around it, and leaving a gap in the middle.


At 22:05, he explains that the corners of the box in higher dimensions are actually really far from the centre. The distance to the nearest face is always 2, but the distance to the nearest sphere is the distance to point (1,1,1...) subtract 1 (the radius). (You might think of this also as the distance to the corner of the inner box - 1).

Because the distance to the corner of the inner box increases with the dimensions, this means the distance to the spheres also increases.

To take this to the extreme, in very high dimensions, you could have the spheres in the corners be really really far away, while the distance to the face of the box is still just 2.

At the moment this won’t really make any sense, but we’re getting there.


In the 2D example (9:45), take one of the circles. It is touching 2 of the other 3 spheres. This leaves 1 of the other 3 that it is not touching. It is not touching (or being) 1 of the 4 spheres, or 1/4.

In 3D (10:35), each sphere touches 3 others leaving 4 untouched out of the 8, or 1/2.

In 4D, each (hyper)sphere touches 4, but the are now 16 spheres, leaving 11/16 untouched!

If you increase this up to 10D, a sphere only touches 10 others, and it leaves the other 99.93% of the spheres untouched!

Because the spheres are so far away, and only linked together by a few, it is kind of like a wire-frame made of spheres!

To represent how the spheres get further away and the gap in the middle gets larger, I like to imagine instead of increasing the dimensions, that you add more sides to each face. So instead of a square of spheres with a gap in the middle as I described earlier (10:35), you might have a pentagon of spheres, or a hexagon, or a decagon, so on until there is a ring of spheres in a circle. Imagine a cube where each face is instead a ring of spheres. You could also just imagine a wireframe of a cube the is made up of lots of little spheres.

They are both equally terrible analogies, but they give an intuitive sense for how it is even possible that the sphere can be bigger than the box.

Imagine this wireframe-like shape, and imagine a sphere in the middle expanding until it is touching the spheres. You can see how the sphere is poking out the edges of this wireframe?

It is very important to remember that this is absolutely not an accurate visual analogy, it is simply a tool to explain and visualise how in higher dimensions, when gap in the spheres gets bigger and bigger while the spheres get further and further away, it actually makes sense that the sphere can poke outside the box.

I have a simpler explanation for this:
When the circles are replaced by spheres, and so on, the length between the edge of the inner circle and where the outer circles meet each other stay the same, regardless of dimensions. the volume on the other hand, is increasing with each dimension.
Therefore, the space between the shapes grow slower than the volume of the shapes themselves as they enter higher dimensions.

If you consider the diagonal line only then you can actually solve this problem purely geometrically in only 1 dimension, you don't even need to analogy 2 and 3 dimensions!

you know the diagonal line gets scaled to sqrt(N) in N dimensions so scale it down so it has length 1, now you have a 0-sphere with radius 1/sqrt(N) from the corner, how big can the 0-sphere from the origin be to just touch it? 1-1/sqrt(N). Now you scale the whole line back up to where it would be in N dimensions by multiplying by sqrt(N) so you get sqrt(N) - 1 which is the answer.

This allows you to then extend to 2 dimesnsions where you can visually see the sphere poking out of the box.
Draw a square and at every corner create a sphere with radius 1/sqrt(N), then draw a circle in the middle that is tangent to all those spheres.
And you can also intuit from this view that the sphere will never be big enough to contain the corners of the box because there is always going to be a nonzero sphere between it and the corners, which is the same as saying sqrt(N) - 1 is always less than sqrt(N).

I was wondering how many cubes there are on a 4D tesseract, and I thought of this video. A unit cube has its sliders capped at -1 and 1. What it means to be on the surface of the cube, but not a corner, is to have exactly one slider locked at one of its limits. So for each dimensional slider, a cube has on its surface an extra two cubes of lower dimensions. Sure enough, a square has 4 lines, a cube has 6 squares, and a tesseract has 8 cubes on its surface.

This method of thinking about dimensions is really good.

As always so grateful for your creative work. After much reflection and reviewing of this video here are a few of my key takeaways.

For problems in 2 and 3 dimensional spaces, finding solutions is greatly helped by our ability to move back and forth between analytical and geometrical expressions of the problem. For problems in higher dimensions we do not have access to this back and forth sharing of insights. Many if not most problems are formulated in these higher dimensions.

This video provides an example of a counterintuitive insight that did not emerge at all in 2 or 3 dimensions. Namely: in higher dimensions the radius of the inner hypersphere, tangent to all N boundary defining unit hyperspheres whose centers are one unit from the origin as measured along any one of the N orthogonal axes is greater than the distance from the origin as measured along any single orthogonal axis to the surface of the N hypercube that encompasses all N unit hyperspheres. This is indeed counterintuitive.

After grokking how you beautifully and skillfully led all of us to this insight, I was able to distil the following. To make the counterintuitive point, there is no need to introduce the growing inner hypersphere at all. Even in 2 and 3 dimensions the distance from the origin of any N dimension space to the center of any boundary defining unit sphere is always greater than one and grows as sqrt(N). So already for N=4, the distance from the origin to the center of any boundary unit hypersphere is greater than the distance along any one orthogonal axis from the origin to a surface of the hypercube that contains all N unit hyperspheres.

The final grok (so far): the core insight is about the concept of distance. Not about radii, not about hyperspheres, not about boundary surfaces of all containing hypercubes. Distance from the origin to the centers of unit hyperspheres as you distribute them will always be significantly greater than the distance from the origin along an axis to any one of the containing hypersurfaces as you define them. Except in 2 or 3 dimensions.

In yet another way: the N dimensional distance from the origin to any center of a unit hypersphere as you distribute them is always greater than the distance from the origin measured on an orthogonal axis to a hypersurface defined by your distribution of the centers of the unit hyperspheres. This is true for 2, 3 and higher dimensions. For the hypersurfaces containing all your unit hyperspheres, the distance from the origin measured along an orthogonal axis to any such hypersurface is always less than the distance from the origin to a center of a contained hypersphere except in 2 and 3 dimensions.

Your videos are more accessible than my words. But my struggle to put the insights from you into these words deepens my ability to grasp what you offer. Thank you so much!

Corrections and/or improvements to my text are most welcome!

To get the idea where does that higher-dimensional inner sphere pokes out of the box: Imagine 3D case with cube, and 8 spheres in its corners. Those spheres cover all the edges of the cube, but they do not cover all the surface of the cube. The centre of the sides is not covered by the corner spheres. And this is the place, where most of the inner sphere "leaks out" of the box in higher dimensions.
In 3 dimensions, the inner sphere cannot reach that areas. However, in higher dimensions, the corners of the cube (and therefore the centers of the corner spheres) are way further away from the centre of the cube, giving more room for inner sphere to grow, eventually reaching to that area.

consider an n-cube where each (n-1) side has a unit length 1. inscribe an n-sphere with a radius of 1 such that the center of the unit n-sphere is at one corner of the n-cube. find the radius of the n-sphere who's center is at the exact opposite corner of the n-cube and is tangent with the unit n-sphere at exactly 1 point.

this is what 3blue1brown did, and explained it step-by-step, noting that if we're talking about more than 4 dimensions then the inner (bounded) n-sphere has a radius greater than 1, and so is BIGGER than the unit n-spheres that "box it in".

There's a problem here. You are measuring using your own finite numbers within your own finite space. You're only measuring toward your own lowest space possible, which is equally amazing to watch. If you want to measure a higher dimension, you must use 0 or ∞, since these values are equal to your finite space. These two numbers, 0 and ∞, mean the same thing. You use them to know which direction you are counting, not as a benchmark to reach the beyond. Whatever numbers you find after 0 or ∞, will be meaningless and without reason, since you can't comprehend them.

Picturing or visualizing infinity / ∞ and 0 is not possible either. It is infinite space between finite spaces. It doesn't take shape or form, because that would be a defined value. So what does that mean? It means that neither can exist without the other. If you didn't have 0, you couldn't have ∞, and vice versa. Picturing infinity as a circled shape is pointless, because that shape isn't defined, it goes on forever. You can look at a circle and say that it is indeed round, but you'll never know until you find the last digit. When you give up counting, that is when you get your circle. Defining a circle is like defining infinity. Defining a number below 1 will also equal to infinity, because 1 is the lowest number possible in finite space. Any number below 1 to 0 will be irrational, which is also true for the other direction. Anything more than 1 will eventually lead to ∞.

If you didn't understand any of that. The numbers you find between 0 to 1, will be equally big to the numbers you find between 1 and ∞. Using the method described here, to cross over, or interact with that which lies beyond is not possible. You'll never run out of irrational numbers. You'd have to travel an infinite amount of space to do so. You'll never reach 0. When you reach the end of your universe, when you are in fact leaving 1 and go toward 0, the absolute lowest number, you will enter irritational space and this is your challenge ahead:
0.........................................................................................................................................................................................................................

If you go the other direction, the result will be the same: 1.........................................................................................................................................................................................................................

This is the finite space you live in.

Visualizing objects in the fourth dimension is actually quite simple as well. Just take that new fourth dimension of location and hold it constant. That constrains the radius of the sphere in the three dimensions so you have a larger or smaller sphere to work with. This is essentially like the way the video constrained the x-dimension of the sphere before showing that it constrained the size of the circle around that point x {x = some constant | (x^2)+(y^2)+(z^2)=(r^2)} (read the "|" symbol as "such that" or "given that").

The size of the sphere then correlates to the distance away from a dimension that is not able to be visually represented by drawing another line through the coordinate set because at every single point in the three dimensions (x,y,z) there will be an origin point and then a positive and negative direction extending out from that in this new fourth dimension (if this were not the case then there would be some points in the three dimensional space where the fourth dimension would never be able to equal some given real number).

This fourth dimension here operates much like gravity. Particles move through three dimensional space, but always rest atop "the fabric of space." So imagine if you would that "the fabric of space" which is a flat surface had observable edges, and that a single particle rested in the middle of that flat sheet of space. Also imagine that this particle resting on space, were the shape of a sphere and would displace the fabric of space until the widest portion of the sphere were in line with the plane of flat space. Now let's assume that this resting point, where the area of the intersection between the spherical particle and the plane of flat space is maximized, is the origin point in the fourth dimension (call it g).

Well then as we pull up on this particle the area of the interception (area of the created circle) would have to decrease. This decrease we could then be translated back into a proportional change in the radius of the sphere(x,y,z), so that lifting the particle to the point where it is tangential to the plane of flat space would be represented by a point somewhere in the (x,y,z) dimension. This is akin to saying the size of the sphere in (x,y,z) space correlates proportionally to the observed mass of the object and that lifting the particle off the surface of space so that the two no longer interact then causes the particle to have no observable mass and therefor cannot be represented in (x,y,z) space.

Just because the distance between a pair of corner points in a unit square is larger than the unit does not mean any of these points lies outside the square's boundary. It only means the more dimension you traverse between two corner points the longer distance, i.e. what you call real estate, you have to travel. The same holds true in any dimensions, and no matter dimensions the enclosed "circle" should still be inside the "square" and never touch it, since this is per definition of how it was constructed.

The way to intuitively grasp this is to think the more dimension you add the more space will be available in the enclosed center, and if more space is available then it follows the max distances inside that space must increase. If you add infinite many dimension it follows the max distance will be infinite inside the enclosed space yet the inner space itself will still be enclosed inside the unit space. Nothing strange happens and all above follows directly from Pythagoras theorem, i.e. the distance function.

Another way to understand how much space is available is to realize you can fit a 1 meter long bar inside a 10 thousand dimensional cube with a side length no longer than 1 centimeter.

The point here is that four dimension spheres are completely different from 3D spheres. The fourth dimension can only have one value at a time.
Take a 2D right angled triangle. Adjacent to the acute angle 'X' is the real dimension, so Y is the opposite dimension and is defined as the √-1 or half way round to being in the -X direction. Not see what x^2 + y^2 is x^2 is unchanged but y^2 is now -|y|^2 so X^2 + y^2 becomes x^2 -y^2 numerically.  

In reality all the spatial dimensions must be at 'imaginary' right angle to the fourth dimension which is ct. Now squaring the x or y or z gives a value in the minus real direction. As the squares are now all pointing in the same direction they can be added. Square rooting swings the result of they addition up into the imaginary plane of our normal three dimensional space. So the fourth dimension is necessary for the existence of the three dimensional space that we see, but the real fourth dimension is invisible to as as we are travelling at the speed of light in that direction.

On higher dimensions and Pythagoras:
Really, the Pythagorean theorem is the diagonal of a square, and you can use it in higher dimensions (I saw it in a Mathologer's video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p-0SOWbzUYI).
For example, in 3D, the diagonal (d) of a rectangular prism with length, height and width a b c, can be described as a^2+b^2+c^2=d^2.
The same is true in 4D, a^2+b^2+c^2+d^2=e^2.
But, if we have a hypercube, so a=b=c=d, then 4a^2=e^2. taking the square root of both sides gives 2a=e.
So the diagonal of 4D hypercube is twice the length of its side.

I think there's also another way to think about high-dim spheres, for example 4D: a*a+b*b+c*c+d*d=1
Imagine a segment with length 1. With 3 cuts divide it into 4 ordered segments with lengths A, B, C, D such that A+B+C+D=1 (here A = a*a, and so on). Then add 4 binary values sgnA, sgnB, sgnC, sgnD in {-1, 1} which indicate the sign of a, b, c, d. So any point on this 4D sphere is a partition of segment of length 1 into 4 parts + 4 bit counter.

Just imagine, what the 3rd bar, by fixing it, caused: The other 2 created a circle, but more importantly, the size of the circel depends on the fixpoint of the 3rd bar. Now to transfrom that to the 4th dimonsion: if we fix 1 bar, the other 3 create a Sphere with a fixed size, so if you change the fixed point, you change the Spheresize. In fact this means a 4d-Sphere with r=1 is a Sphere which has all sizes between r=0 & r=1 at the same time. Additionally it has more hidden spheres there, when you choose a different fixpoint. Here's another way to visualize the "real estate", as points on a surface in 3D. Picture the sliders lying on the xy-plane, one for each dimension at consecutive integers in the x-direction. Then instead of the graded lines up and down the sliders, raise each slider up in the z-direction in the shape of a parabola (zi=yi^2). Now for points on a sphere in N dimensions, the z values for each parabola should add up linearly to 1. Cool thing with this is you can easily generalize to other surfaces and volumes by changing the curve/surface and the way the heights add up.

You can project 4D->3D or 4D->2D. In 4D->2D, you can slice along (1,0,0,0) and (0,1,1,1), thus getting a rectangle of size 2 x (2*sqrt(3)) with a circle in each corner. In 4D->3D, you can slice along (1,0,0,0), (0,1,0,0) and (0,0,1,1) -- then you'd be looking at a box of size 2 x 2 x (2*sqrt(2)) with a sphere in each corner.

This also generalizes into higher dimensions, where the rectangle (or the box) keep getting wider.

You know, what intermittently occurs to me about computer displays (as they typically are in modern form) is that they are not in fact 2 dimensional display devices.

If you think it through, you realise they actually display 5 dimensions. At least, in a non-spatial sense.

Why is this? Well, consider what a computer display actually is showing you;

It's a flat plane broken up into small lights. These are called pixels.
Let's first assume it's a black and white display.

If you consider drawing a point with this display, how much data do you need?
An X and Y coordinate, right? 2 dimensions.

But... Actually, no. You are implicitly assuming something here - that the point you are drawing is distinct from everything else on the display somehow.
Thus, you are presuming a state value for the display element
On a Pure black and white display, the state of a pixel can be black (off) or white (on)
But this is still an extra piece of data.
So our full specification for a point on such a display is 3 numbers:
X coordinate, Y coordinate, and state (on/off)

Let's upgrade to monochrome. This changes things from a binary on/off state, to a range of values. Typically on most displays since the 90's this has been 8 bits, so 256 values, though it can be less (or more).
Now, this starts to look very much like a third axis doesn't it?
Yes, all the possible 'positions' are discrete integer values, but that's true of the X and Y coordinate as well, given they represent a 2d grid of discrete elements. You cannot light up a pixel at coordinate 2.5 by 4.8 on the display. You can only approximate this. (by rounding to the nearest integer, or antialiasing the point, which effectively uses our brightness dimension to mask limitations in our spatial dimensions.)

OK, so maybe you're starting to see something here;
Let's say we have a monochrome 320x240 display with 8 bit depth.
To specify the state of a single pixel fully, requires an X coordinate, a Y coordinate, and a brightness value.
So in fact in a mathematical sense our display is the integer coordinates in 3d space in a rectangular prism volume of size 320 units, by 240 units, by 256 units.

Do you see where this leads?
That's right.
Colour displays generally have 3 'brightness' values (one each for Red, Green, And Blue), and thus a point is specified in 5 dimensions on such a display.
Now, granted, 3 of those dimensions are representing something you don't typically think of as a 'dimension', but mathematically it's clearly analogous.
This leads to the obvious conclusion that if you sacrifice all colour data (and thus lighting and so on), you have a 5 dimensional display device sitting in front of you, and could visualise 5 dimensional geometry this way.

There are some obvious limitations and restrictions here though;
While in your two spatial dimensions you can display every integer point within the display bounds simultaneously, our colour data is restricted to defining exactly one point in each dimension.

However, conceptually this is true of projecting 3d objects onto a 2d image plane as well.
It's why you cannot see the back side of a cube when looking at it's front side. (unless it's transparent).

There is a way to animate a point moving on a sphere of arbitrary dimension. To start, consider drawing a circle with only 1D graphics: it is a sequence of points that move away from eachother then rejoin. If the circle is projected down it turns into a line which isn't very helpful to a 1D creature, but if it has memory we can ask it to visualize several snapshots of point pairs. Similarly we can imagine several circles of ascending and descending radius to form a 3D sphere, a point can either move along its circle or jump to the corresponding point on the adjacent circles. Similarly we can draw an array of 3D spheres, it is not hard to picture a point moving around on this 4D sphere and with a little effort one can try holding an array of arrays of 3D spheres in memory. This process can be iterated arbitrarily with sufficient approximation: draw a grid where each box represents 3D space, put a sphere in the middle tile then iteratively put smaller spheres in each adjacent tile; Contain this grid in a bigger box and then make a grid of such containers, and so on

Summation video:

1) The n-dimensional sphere consists of tuples (x1,...xn) of real numbers with the sum of xi^2 = 1 (in analogy to 2 and 3 dimensions).
2) The sphere centred at the origin and tangent to that centred at a corner of the box of side length 2 has radius sqrt(N) - 1. This is really easy to prove (one just shows that, say, the coordinates of the intersection of this central sphere and that at (1,1,..,1) has all equal coordinates, then just use the definition of the Euclidean metric).
3) Therefore the sphere touches the sides of the box for N=4 and goes outside of the box for N>4. It's radius is unbounded as N increases.
4) This is different to the pictures we see for N=1,2,3.
5) Obviously you can think of a point of (x1,...,xn) as points on a bunch of "sliders".

Since the approach used does not produce a sensible result
why not “invent new math” and try to find an approach that does? 

Why should it be that the “distance” between two points in n-space
should equal the square root of a sum of the squared distances?  We naturally lean to this rule because we live in a 3D world. But other definitions are possible.In (n+1) dimensions why not define distance r as  r^n = x1^n + x2^n +x3^n +…… + x(n+1)^n   that is the nth root of the sum of the (n+1) orthogonal distances taken to the nth power.  In 3D we have n=2 and the familiar rules drop out (noting that what we call 2D is really 3D with one of the coordinates fixed and equal to zero).

In (n+1) D the “distance” between the centre of the in-sphere and each of the unit spheres would be equal to (n+1)^(1/n). As n gets large this tends to 1, but is always greater than 1. So the radius of the in-sphere will tend to zero and therefore the in-sphere always lies within the boundary of the containing box. This is intuitively more sensible than a formulation that results in the in-sphere growing infinitely large.

In 4D a sphere would be defined by the equation x^3+y^3+z^3+w^3 = r^3 where r is a constant.  This has one real and two complex solutions for all combinations of the three independent variables, which at first looks like a problem. But in 3D with our normal definition of distance x^2+y^2+z^2 = r^2 has either two real or two complex solutions and we happily ignore the inconvenient complex pairs.

After watching this video I started thinking "what might the 4th dimension actually be?". Speaking geometrically, each n-dimensional entity is made up of an infinite number of stacked (n-1)-dimensional entities. Basically, a square is made up of an infinite number of lines, a cube is made up of an infinite number of squares, and so on. Now, each time you stack a number of n-dimensional objects on top of each other, they tangent each other, but never touch. In terms of our world, that would mean parallel worlds are what make up the 4th dimension. Basically meaning, if we were able to move between parallel worlds, we'd be moving along the 4th dimension, or the w axis.

But let's take a look at something else. Each n-dimensional entity basically "limits" the number of (n-1)-dimensional entities that fit within it based on the length of its nth dimension. That means that only a certain number of stacked (n-1)-dimensional entities make up an n-dimensional entity, whose size we decide based on the nth dimension of that entity. What that means is that while the nth dimension can't be perceived by the (n-1)-dimensional entity, the nth dimension still exists for it and goes through it. Now, by going through something, you're obviously going to decide something in it, and what dimensions are deciding is structure. For example, our 3-dimensional world only allows a fixed amount of 2-dimensional entities to "exist". We can't create any new shape that's 2-dimensional. 2D entities are always going to be some type of polygon. That's what makes them 2D, it's their unique "trait", their structure. I'm using the world "structure" here for a reason. What structure do we have that might differentiate between parallel worlds and make similar parallel worlds able to be grouped up and put on an axis? Logical structure. We can be certain that there is an infinite number of parallel worlds in existence. If there was only 1 singular and rock solid logic, then there'd be no room for any parallel worlds. Each decision we end up making, we make based on our own logical thinking and what we perceive as the best option. In a parallel world, we took the other option, because the logical structure there is ever so slightly different and we thought of the other option as the more logical one. The only thing that could differentiate parallel worlds in general is the logical structure of that world. The law of that world. That would mean that once we start moving across parallel worlds, once we start moving across the w axis, we'll see extremely similar worlds to our own at first, almost identical, as they are the closest to us by logical structure. Basically, the first quintillions of parallel worlds we go through are gonna have the most minute differences on the atomic level. It'll literally be a matter of if one single atom is 1e-99999999 m moved to either side of either the x, y or z axis compared to the parallel world you came from.

This also leads to my thoughts about the 5th dimension being time. Time will move in all of the parallel worlds we go through just the same as it is moving here. But in another set of infinite parallel worlds, time will move differently and that will differentiate the 4th dimensional "universes" from each other. At least that's my own thoughts on the matter.

Another neat property to investigate is the relationship between the area of a square and a circle, and their equivalents in high-D. In 2D most of the square is taken up by the circle. Which is perfectly logical. The higher you go, the less the circle takes of the square. It might seems very strange until you look at the difference - what's the difference between the square and circle in 2D? Just 4 corners! In 3D the difference is 8 corners. In 5D the difference becomes 32 corners - that's a heck of a lot of hypercube that's not part of the hypersphere.

This is really not all that helpful. Far better is to take your cue from quaternions. A quaternion visualizes the first three dimensions as a vector in a conventional orthogonal projection, and visualizes the 4th dimension as a rotation about the axis of the vector. Generalizing, the 4th and higher dimensions can represent any arbitrary transformatio of a vector or tensor or an animated object standing in for a vector or tensor.

Say for instance that we wish to represent 6 dimensions. We can orient and size a figure of a man according to the vector determined by the first three dimensions, the man's head being at the arrow head, the man's feet being at the origin. The direction the man faces is determined by the 4th dimension, the man's hands can point in the directions of the 5th and 6th dimensions, or alternatively, the lengths of his arms can be determined by the 5th and 6th dimensions. Other dimensions can control other details of the figure, such as the length of his hair or the size of the brim of his sombrero. Your imagination is the limit!

Visualizing purely abstract mathematical dimensions isn't the problem. The problem is that those higher dimensions don't exist in physical reality. Not even the three dimension, since they are imaginary and based on a non-existent point. It's all a distraction from the real hyper-dimensions that are physically observable, everywhere, because EVERY thing IS  a dimension - an extension of what it is a part of. Real hyper-dimensions are a manifestation of the generalized universal principle of whole/part duality. Remember K.I.S.S.?

You can't pack 2 dimensional objects in 3 dimensional space (yes, you can fit them in there, but it would never fill it). Thus, you can't pack spheres in 8d or 24d space either. Also...space is, from what I understand, limited to 3d anyway, due to space being a synonym for volume...so it's wrong to say "8d space".

The problem with ALL videos on this subject is that they are a sham.
You can know everything there is to know about a higher-dimensional object, you can describe it in perfect detail, but you can NEVER visualise it. Saying you can visualise, say a hypercube, is a bit like saying you can smell the colour green or taste the colour purple. It's a category error.
Only 3-dimensional objects are visualisable. You can never visualise anything 1- or 2-dimensional either. A line segment drawn on a sheet of paper is not 1- but 3-dimensional: it's a collection of 3-dimensional ink molecules. And the surface of a table isn't 2-dimensional: it's a sheet of 3-dimensional molecules.

How to sort of visualize a 4D sphere. Take a 2D transparent flat surface and have a 3D sphere pass through it. The cross section of the sphere going through the flat plane will look like a dot appearing out of nowhere gradually growing from a point into a circle and as the sphere is half way through it it reverses the order and goes from a circle shrinking back down into a dot and disappearing.

Now take that same logic with a 4D hyper sphere. Imagine a 3D cube as a chunk of space the 4D hyper sphere passes through. It starts out with a small dot appearing into existence inside the cube and it grows into a large sphere and after the 4D hyper sphere is half way through the square it slowly starts to shrink again into a small dot and disappearing.

It is very interesting approach that allows for some really powerful analytics in nD, but I think that you needed to take a deeper dive into it showing it with different equations from analytical geometry and maybe some engineering/physics problems(like Bernoulli equations for example).

Going further towards the fun stuff can we generate a wave(sinusoidal) function that corresponds to the scale you gave for a sphere(or other base equations).
That function will be:
1. the same for all dimensions if we consider a symmetrical constructs,
2. will come in a matrix form to represent sub or super symmetrical constructs.
3. will be continuous for finite objects(instances) in nD that have volume
4. will be decaying for infinite types/classes(like exponential functions for example) in nD
5. will exist in its own dimensional space that defines 3 analytical dimensions around an parametric 0 point(a handle of some sort)
- density over distance to handle(how much work is done for a single change),
- volume over density(how much work must the other dimensions do over single change),
- handle feedback(additional characterization allowing for spatial movement depending on dimensional changes, not really useful for analytical bodies)

It will visualize similar to the particle decay diagram where the particles are replaced with the dimensions and the transmissions between those are reflect the work that is 'delegated' to the other dimensions where one must be able to code the dimension in groups in cases of strange symmetries.

The latter will require 3D visualization with one logical dimension axis in the center used to track/id the instances acting as a center for a cylinder on which surface the dimensions are drawn. The transactions are effectively planes(sub-spaces) in the cylinder that connect its logical axis and the surface and may be shown as axes(or cylinders) inside the cylinder itself

If we go for a play and approach the surface of the cylinder chosen for visualization of our unit/wave functions as a cluster of module spaces that are layered on each other and forced to project themselves in-between the stack.

the 9 dimensional version of this is really cool. With 9 dimensions, the center of the outer spheres, which is centered at the point (1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1), is a distance of sqrt(9), or 3 units in radius away from the origin. Since we know that the radius of each outside sphere is 1, by definition, we know that the furthest point from the origin on any of the outside spheres is 3+1, or 4 units away from the origin. keep this in mind for later.

Keep in mind that the outer sphere is still centered at (1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1), despite that the distance between the center of that sphere and the origin is 3.

When looking at the point of intersection between the outside and the inside spheres, we can see that the dimensional component of any one of the dimensions between the point of intersection and the center of the outer sphere is sqrt(1/9). since we know that the total dimensional component of any dimension between the origin and the center of the outer sphere is 1, the dimensional component of any one of the dimensions of the inner sphere must be 1-sqrt(1/9). We can now use this dimensional component to calculate the radius of the inner sphere. Each dimension is 1-sqrt(1/9), so using the formula for distance, we can see the radius of the inner sphere is (((1 - sqrt(1/9))^2)*9). Since we know that the square root of 1/9 is 1/3, we can easily simplify this into (((1 - (1/3))^2)*9). Then we get (9*((2/3)^2)). Then 9*(4/9), which simplifies to 4. So in conclusion, the radius of the INNER sphere is 4. Remember from earlier how I noted that the furthest point from the origin on any of the inner sphere is 4 units away from the origin. The implication of this is that every OUTSIDE sphere is ENTIRELY INSIDE of the INSIDE sphere. With 9 dimensions that would be 512 outer spheres encased inside the inner sphere.

Great video. I wanted to share something interesting I noticed about higher dimensional spheres. Take two points at (uniformly) random locations on the surface and measure the angle between them from the origin. On a high-D hypersphere (say, 50) this angle is likely to be very close to 90 degrees and vanishingly unlikely to be anywhere near 0 (nearby) or 180 (polar opposites).

It'd be lonely living on a 50-D planet since everyone else would be half a world away.

The way I usually visualise high-dimensional stuff is to pick out 2 or 3 dimensions of interest and draw what the continuous shape looks like when all the other dimensions are set to constants. I then imagine these as frames along orthogonal axes of the other dimensions (kind of like the sliders). You essentially end up with axes of axes of axes of axes etc.
I think part of the problem is that we try to imagine a mix of dimensions placing n-dimensional objects in 3-dimensional space.

You should have added the following for the ones who didn't notice it (probably lots of viewers):
The hypercube's center-to-vertex distance is root(N) while the centered hypersphere has radius root(N) - 1, since you substract the unitary radius of the vertex-centered hyperspheres. The centered hypersphere will certainly have some parts outside the hypercube, since root(N) - 1 may be bigger than 2 (hypercube's edge). Nevertheless, the hypercube's vertex' are all outside the hypersphere regardless of the dimension, as well as the vertex-centered hyperspheres remain outside and tangent to the centered hypersphere.
An easy analogy to this phenomenon would be to see the case of 2d with shrinking vertex-centered circles. The centered circle can be partially outside the square but will not be totally outside if the vertex-centered circles' radius doesn't drop beneath 0 (similar to the quotient between outer and centered hyperspheres radius).

This might not be obvious to the public so it should be included in the video, but it doesn't take too much effort or mathematical skills to figure it out.

The "dimensions" of math and the "dimensions" of physics are two different things entirely. While the physicist uses qualifying statements (i.e. direction and orthogonality), math is only concerned with quantity (i.e. ordered triplett). Both are entirely different concepts yet here we are treating n-dimensional "spheres" as "real". They are as real as epicycles, a crutch used to explain away things we don't understand yet.

I think I thought of a way to see how the inner sphere touches the sides of the 4D hypercube.
Imagine the 4th dimension as pointing inward from the vertices of the 3-cube, and if the 3-cube has side length 2, the the length pointed in ward will be 2, now connect all the points such that you construct an "inner cube". The inner cube is not actually smaller it's just further away into the 4th dimension.
Now in order to imagine the centre of the hyper cube, take the point halfway between each vertice between the outer and inner cube.
After connecting all those points and forming a third cube between the outer and inner you simply take the centre of this new cube. Now any point on this new cube will be and equal distance away from the corresponding points on both the inner and outer cubes, including the centre point, therefore this must be the centre. Now set up a hypersphere centered at this point. If the radius is 1, the sphere will contact the middle cube.

The way I visualize higher than 3 dimensions is to just repeat them. In 1 dimension you're walking back and forth on an X axis.  Make it 2 dimensions and you're walking graph paper. Add another dimension and you're walking around on a cube.  So you have your XYZ coordinates in space.  To give your coordinates in space-time, you are walking on the cube, but the cube is sliding on its own relative X coordinate which is W. In 5 dimensions, the cube has its own relative XY coordinates which and are WV in a global view. Then we get to WVU with you traveling about on a cube while it travels around on a cube.  And it repeats again with the second cube sliding back and forth on its own line.

25:35 8*pi

One intuitive/visual way to solve it (it takes much longer to explain what I saw than it took me to see it):

Imagine the background tessellated with equilateral triangles of sidelength AB (i.e. the radius of the two circles), using the points A and B as "starting" vertices. You'd see a hexagon inscribed in each of the two circles. The intersection points of the two circles would also become vertices of the tessellation-triangles, because both of these two points are exactly one radius away from A and B. If you only concentrate on one circle, you can see that two inscribed triangles worth of angle get lost in terms of circle circumference. That is one third of the total circumference (2 triangles worth of circumference out of the 6 triangles making up the inscribed hexagon; other way to think: 2 triangles worth of angle are 120° which is a third of 360°). Thus, the remaining circumference for each circle is 2/3 of it's original circumference. As we have two circles (one around A, one around B), the red line (L) is 4/3 times the circle circumference. One circumference C=2*r*pi thus the red line
L = 4/3*2*r*pi = 8/3*r*pi Now we can plug in r=3 and get L=8*pi

Hi 3Blue1Brown, I'm aware that the goal of this video was to provide a way to show non-visualizable problems. I just wanted to provide a way to still visualize the problem mentioned in the video that helped me to rationalize the size of the inner sphere. One thin that always stays 1-dimensional is the diagonal of one side of the d-dim box. In 2 dimensions this is just the actual edge, in 3 dimensions it is the diagonal of the face of the box and so on. The keypoint is that this diagonal has length 2*Sqrt[d-1] (d = dimension), whereas the outer spheres continue to have radius 1.
You can now draw a box with vertical length equal to 2*Sqrt[d-1] and horizontal length equal to 2 (the original length of the box) and 4 circles of radius 1 in each corner. The inner circle touches all 4, as postulated in the problem. It is clear from that picture, that the inner circle becomes larger and larger as the vertical side of the box (=the diagonal of the side of the box) grows with the dimension.
I don't know if it is any good, but this picture helped me to wrap my head around this dimensionality issue.

One could argue that you can't fill in all 8 cubes in 3D space, because the "outer" cube will already be full, but in this case the 4D hypercube is just open on one side, but it's still hollow and empty. That's the extra space you get in the 4th dimension.

One way of thinking about the fact that the measure of a unit sphere seems to 'shrink' relative to the measure of a unit cube as dimensions increase is: To turn a circle in a square 3-dimensional, first extrude it. Now it's a cylinder in a cube, and it has the same volume proportions as the previous version had area proportions. Shave off the extra volume so that the cylinder becomes a sphere. So each time you scale it up into higher dimensions, you extrude and shave. And each time the n-sphere loses measure relative to the n-cube.

I got curious if and when the n-dimensional volume of the inner sphere surpasses the total volume of all the corner spheres, and it turns out that at 9 dimensions, both the volume of the inner sphere and the total volume of the outer spheres are equal to 1688.8365582... units of space. 10 dimensions is the first one where the inner sphere surpasses the outer spheres, doing so with a volume ratio of more than 2.
For 9 dimensions, the volume ratio is exactly 1, and all other dimensions where the ratio is an integer are n-dimensional, where n is the square of an odd number, so 1D, 9D, 25D, 49D, etc. The ratio at 25D is 33554432, and it grows exponentially.

As a computer science student, I've had to deal with some of the weirdnes of high-dimensional spaces up close, when using geometric methods to analyze high-dimensional data. The unit cube alone is so incredibly weird.. mainly because it has an exponential amount of corners. Meaning that if you slice off even a tiny region surrounding each corner (and they are all at east distance 1 apart, so these tiny regions don't overlap, and therefore add up directly), those tiny regions comprise nearly all the volume of the cube.
You can sort of say that properties that can arise from the actions of single dimensions are common, while properties that only arise with the "agreement" of many dimensions is rare. It's even sort of hard to create a large high-dimensional volume, because all of the dimensions have to be large together, if even one of them is small, the volume is small. It also has it's good sides, it means when we do optimization problems, we rarely have to worry about local extrema, since they can only happen if all dimensions curve in the same direction, whih is difficult to arrange.
